comments.author: vegetarianperspective
comments.content: Like all your work, exceptional!

comments.author: Cate
comments.content: I've only made one crostata in my life, but I loved how much less stressful it was than worrying about fussy pie dough and making it look perfect.

comments.author: John - Mormon Foodie
comments.content: With peach season just around the corner in my neck of the woods, this will be wonderful.

comments.author: thepinkpeppercorn
comments.content: Looks absolutely delicious!  Love it!!

comments.author: Ivys Manning
comments.content: Now everyone will know our secret! Those of us who are lousy crimpers make crostatas. In all fairness I told my husband before we married that my pies look rather sad. He married me based on my crostada. I fill mine with grilled veggies and cheese, but I've never tried peach. Will give it a go and let you know. I bet vanilla ice cream is lovely with this. Looks like a weekend project! Thanks!

comments.author: tara
comments.content: I adore crostatas, they are so much more forgiving than a proper pie and is just as good. The way you've arranged the fruit is lovely - it looks like a golden rosebud.

comments.author: JMom
comments.content: I think there's still time for me to get some peaches. This looks absolutely delicious!

comments.author: Jess
comments.content: Looks awesome!!! Been reading your blog for a little while, loveee it! Your post on why your a vegetarian kicked ass, i totally agree!

comments.author: Ivys Manning
comments.content: Michael- I made this and brought it to a potluck, it was a great hit! I didn't have nectarines, just Maryhill peaches, it was delovely anyway. I added the innards of 1/2 of a vanilla bean to the peaches, cuz you know, that's how I roll. But I followed everything else to the letter and it was really yummy and easy. One guest at the potluck asked if I might be able to bottle the caramelized peach juices that oozed out one corner. He said he'd pay me a million dollars for a liter of it.  Thanks for making me look good!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Thanks Ivy! The vanilla bean sounds like a keen addition. God it is so true
about those caramelized peach juices. You are awfully generous to let those
get to the table, I usually snarf those up in the kitchen :).

comments.author: Arielle
comments.content: Having just gone peach picking, and absolutely loving rustic "pies," I was really excited to try this with peaches only, and was richly rewarded. The crust was flaky, and the peach/butter/sugar combination for the filling created these pockets of sweet-tart peachy jam. Thank you so much for this recipe. It was a huge hit, and will be part of my regular not-pie repertoire.

comments.author: Tiffany
comments.content: I made this for my in-laws the other night and it was divine. I used 2 nectarines & 2 peaches. My mother-in-law raved about the pastry calling it "almost there". Here aunt used to make THE BEST pastry crusts. They would melt in your mouth! So "almost there" is really a great compliment. Thanks for sharing the recipe, it was yummy, yummy!!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I definitely consider "almost there" to be a compliment in this context!

comments.author: c
comments.content:
your pie crust recipe is now my official "pie crust to make for all flaky pie crust recipes" recipe.  the crust was flaky and not too buttery but soft. and it came together so quickly!

I do have one question.  The inner part where the fruit resides had a lot of liquid left over when it finished baking. i actually had to use a baster to take some out so the thing wouldn't fall apart. should i let the peaches sit with some sugar before i put in them in the pastry next time?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Glad you like the crust ! If you are having problems with too much liquid,
you could do as you say and macerate the peaches first to draw off some
liquid, or pre-saute them.

comments.author: Ellen
comments.content: Great sounding recipe and easily made gluten free by subbing in a mixture of GF flours (include xanthan gum). I made one tonite and it came out great. Thanks for your wonderful blog!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Thanks Ellen! I love to hear from vegan and gluten-free readers about the
substitutions they make; I have no expertise in those areas so I think you
are helping out other readers who may want to alter my recipes.

Thanks,
Michael

comments.author: alice
comments.content: Gorgeous fruit crostata!

comments.author: Abigail
comments.content: how do you print out these recipes?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Hi Abigail - unfortunately, I don't have a reasonable print function on the blog. The best you can do is use the print function in your browser and limit it to the first 2 pages. I'm going to be upgrading to a new platform at some point and then print functionality is high on the list.


Thanks,
Michael

comments.author: June
comments.content: Thank you!  I went searching for something with nectarines and peaches and your recipe popped up - hmmmmm, I pondered.  I threw this together tonight. I am among those who cannot make a "pretty" pie.  I may never bake a conventional pie again - the textures were gorgeous & complementary - not too sweet and it allowed the fruit to be fruit (I did grind some cinnamon over it).  Am now pondering a crostata with apples, onions and raisins...
